content: Thanks! The notation \< a , a_in_my_interval_a_b h \> is what I was searching for. I am writing these definitions on my own to learn how to deal with more complicated constructions, but thanks for the references to the docs, it is always good to see how things are done there. Also thanks for the conceptual clear up about a (the?) difference of classes and structures being that there should only be one canonical class.
Raphael Appenzeller has marked this topic as resolved.
Yeah group is a class and subgroup is a structure, because given a type G there is 99% of the time one group structure on G, but given a group G there is 99% of the time more than one subgroup of G.
